The factors of `n` are the prime divisors

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), List.toFinset (Nat.factors n) = Finset.filter Nat.Prime (Nat.divisors n)
name: Nat.prime_divisors_eq_to_filter_divisors_prime
docString: The factors of `n` are the prime divisors

For any natural number n, n divides 1 if and only if n = 1.

name: Nat.dvd_one
docString: For any natural number n, n divides 1 if and only if n = 1.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, `n` divides 1 if and only if `n` is equal to 1. In terms of number theory, this means that 1 can only be divided evenly (i.e., without remainder) by the number 1 itself.

name: Nat.dvd_one
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, `n` divides 1 if and only if `n` is equal to 1. In terms of number theory, this means that 1 can only be divided evenly (i.e., without remainder) by the number 1 itself.

The only divisors of prime powers are prime powers.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [dec_irr : (p : Associates α) → Decidable (Irreducible p)]
  [inst_1 : UniqueFactorizationMonoid α] [dec : DecidableEq α] [dec' : DecidableEq (Associates α)] {a p : Associates α},
  Irreducible p →
    ∀ [inst_2 : (n : ℕ) → Decidable (a ∣ p ^ n)] {n : ℕ} (h : a ∣ p ^ n),
      a = p ^ Nat.find (_ : ∃ n, (fun n => a ∣ p ^ n) n)
name: Associates.eq_pow_find_of_dvd_irreducible_pow
docString: The only divisors of prime powers are prime powers.

For all natural numbers $n$, $1$ is a proper divisor of $n$ if and only if $n$ is a positive integer.

name: Nat.one_mem_properDivisors_iff_one_lt
docString: For all natural numbers $n$, $1$ is a proper divisor of $n$ if and only if $n$ is a positive integer.

This theorem states that for every natural number `p`, if `p` is a prime number, then the set of proper divisors of `p` is the set that contains only the number `1`. In mathematical terms, it establishes that the proper divisors of a prime number `p` are only `1`, since prime numbers are defined as those natural numbers greater than 1 that have no other divisors besides `1` and themselves.

name: Nat.Prime.properDivisors
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `p`, if `p` is a prime number, then the set of proper divisors of `p` is the set that contains only the number `1`. In mathematical terms, it establishes that the proper divisors of a prime number `p` are only `1`, since prime numbers are defined as those natural numbers greater than 1 that have no other divisors besides `1` and themselves.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

name: Nat.dvd_left_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

An equivalent definition for prime powers: `n` is a prime power iff there is a unique prime
dividing it.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, IsPrimePow n ↔ ∃! p, Nat.Prime p ∧ p ∣ n
name: isPrimePow_iff_unique_prime_dvd
docString:
An equivalent definition for prime powers: `n` is a prime power iff there is a unique prime
dividing it.

`Ω n` is the number of prime factors of `n`.

name: Nat.ArithmeticFunction.termΩ
docString: `Ω n` is the number of prime factors of `n`.

Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

name: Nat.factorization_inj
docString: Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

The only prime divisor of positive prime power `p^k` is `p` itself

type: ∀ {k p : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → Nat.Prime p → (p ^ k).primeFactors = {p}
name: Nat.primeFactors_prime_pow
docString: The only prime divisor of positive prime power `p^k` is `p` itself

`ω n` is the number of distinct prime factors of `n`.

name: Nat.ArithmeticFunction.cardDistinctFactors
docString: `ω n` is the number of distinct prime factors of `n`.

The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself, with multiplicity `1`

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → Nat.factorization p = fun₀ | p => 1
name: Nat.Prime.factorization
docString: The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself, with multiplicity `1`

`n : ℕ` is perfect if and only the sum of the proper divisors of `n` is `n` and `n`
is positive.

name: Nat.Perfect
docString:
`n : ℕ` is perfect if and only the sum of the proper divisors of `n` is `n` and `n`
is positive.

The only numbers with empty prime factorization are `0` and `1`

name: Nat.factorization_eq_zero_iff'
docString: The only numbers with empty prime factorization are `0` and `1`

The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself.

type: ∀ {p q : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → (Nat.factorization p) q ≠ 0 → p = q
name: Nat.Prime.eq_of_factorization_pos
docString: The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself.

If the factorization of `n` contains just one number `p` then `n` is a power of `p`

type: ∀ {n p k : ℕ}, n ≠ 0 → (Nat.factorization n = fun₀ | p => k) → n = p ^ k
name: Nat.eq_pow_of_factorization_eq_single
docString: If the factorization of `n` contains just one number `p` then `n` is a power of `p`

A number that divides an `n`-smooth number is itself `n`-smooth.

type: ∀ {n m k : ℕ}, m ∈ Nat.smoothNumbers n → k ∣ m → k ≠ 0 → k ∈ Nat.smoothNumbers n
name: Nat.mem_smoothNumbers_of_dvd
docString: A number that divides an `n`-smooth number is itself `n`-smooth.

The multiplicity of prime `p` in `p` is `1`

name: Nat.Prime.factorization_self
docString: The multiplicity of prime `p` in `p` is `1`

The prime factors of n, regarded as a multiset

name: PNat.factorMultiset
docString: The prime factors of n, regarded as a multiset

A prime natural number is prime in `ℤ[i]` if and only if it is `3` mod `4`

name: GaussianInt.prime_iff_mod_four_eq_three_of_nat_prime
docString: A prime natural number is prime in `ℤ[i]` if and only if it is `3` mod `4`

Two pnats are coprime if their gcd is 1.

name: PNat.Coprime
docString: Two pnats are coprime if their gcd is 1.

`n` is a prime power if there is a prime `p` and a positive natural `k` such that `n` can be
written as `p^k`.

type: {R : Type u_1} → [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] → R → Prop
name: IsPrimePow
docString:
`n` is a prime power if there is a prime `p` and a positive natural `k` such that `n` can be
written as `p^k`.

The type of prime numbers

name: Nat.Primes
docString: The type of prime numbers
